info.description: This is an API for the identity management on ctrX devices.
info.title: ctrlX OS - Authorization and Authentication API

get.description: Function retrieves the password hash of a user which consists of the algorithm, salt and the hashed password (id$salt$hash) as found inside the password file.

200.description: Current password hash of the user with format id$salt$hash

400.description: The request is incomplete or malformed

500.description: Something unexpected happened on the server

get.summary: Get the password hash of a user

put.description: Changes the password (hash) of the user with the specified id. Only administrators are allowed to change the passwords of other users. Regular users need to supply the current password to set a new password (hash). The password can be directly supplied in hashed form if the corresponding query parameter is set.

parameters.description: If true the new password is expected to be a hash value consisting of algorithm, salt and hash value (id$salt$hash). This hash value will be stored inside the password file as the new user's password. If the query parameter is false, the new password is expected to be a string value which will be hashed by some password hashing function prior to being stored inside the password file.
parameters.name: hashed

requestBody.description: New and current password (hash) (optional for admin users)

400.description: The request is incomplete or malformed

401.description: Not authorized to access this resource

409.description: Conflict with the current state of the resource

500.description: Something unexpected happened on the server

put.summary: Change the password (hash) of a user

Unauthorized.description: Not authorized to access this resource

Conflict.description: Conflict with the current state of the resource

InternalServerError.description: Something unexpected happened on the server

sessionTimeout.description:
The sessionTimeout property refers to the duration of time that a user session remains active before it automatically expires. 
It determines how long a user can remain idle or inactive before being logged out of the system for security purposes. 
By setting a specific session timeout value, administrators can control the length of time a user can stay logged in without any activity, ensuring that inactive sessions are terminated to prevent unauthorized access. 
The value should be 0, or a positive value smaller than 3124224000 seconds.
Setting the sessionTimeout property to 0 means that the user sessions will not expire automatically.

maxTicketsPerUser.description:
The maxTicketsPerUser property specifies the maximum number of failed login attempts that a user can make without any subsequent waiting period. 
It sets a limit on the number of unsuccessful login attempts allowed for a user before they are required to wait before trying again. 
By defining a value for maxTicketsPerUser, administrators can control the number of consecutive failed login attempts a user can make without triggering a waiting period. 
The value must be 0 or a positive number.
Setting maxTicketsPerUser to 0 indicates that there is no limit on the number of failed login attempts a user can make, providing unlimited attempts without any waiting period. 
This property helps enhance security by preventing brute-force attacks and unauthorized access attempts.

maxSessionsPerUser.description:
The maxSessionsPerUser property determines the maximum number of concurrent sessions that a user can have at the same time. 
It sets a limit on the number of active login sessions that a user can establish, helping to control and manage the user's access to the system. 
By setting a specific value for maxSessionsPerUser, administrators can restrict the number of simultaneous sessions a user can have, preventing excessive or unauthorized access to the system. 
This property ensures that users cannot have an unlimited number of concurrent sessions, promoting better security and preventing potential misuse or abuse of system resources. 
The value must be 0 or a positive number.
Setting the maxSessionsPerUser property to 0 means that users can have an unlimited number of concurrent sessions.

ticketValidity.description:
The ticketValidity property refers to the duration of time, measured in seconds, that a user must wait after a failed login attempt before they can try again. 
It sets a waiting period or cooldown time to prevent repeated login attempts in quick succession, which helps to enhance security and protect against brute-force attacks. 
By specifying a value for ticketValidity, administrators can control the length of time a user must wait before they can retry logging in after a failed attempt. 
This property acts as a deterrent against unauthorized access attempts and strengthens the overall security of the user management system.
The value should be a positive value smaller than 3124224000 seconds.

tokenValidity.description:
The tokenValidity property defines the maximum duration of a user session before they are automatically logged out. 
It specifies the length of time, measured in seconds, that a user can remain logged in. 
By setting a value for tokenValidity, administrators can control the maximum session duration and enforce automatic logout after the specified period. 
The value should be 0, or a positive value smaller than 3124224000 seconds.
Setting tokenValidity to 0 indicates that there is no limit on the session duration, allowing users to remain logged in for an unlimited amount of time.

UserSettings.description: Contains user specific settings as key-value-pairs of type string.

NamedPasswordPolicy.description: Named set of password policy with a unique id

id.description:
The identifier of the named password policy. When not provided upon creation, the identifier will be
generated by the backend. Otherwise, the backend will use the identifier given that the id follows the
defined pattern.

Credentials.description: Credentials of a user. Include username and password.

User.description: The "User" object is a representation of the properties associated with a user on the system. It serves as a container for various user-related information and attributes.

name.description:
The "name" property represents the user's username.
It is a string that uniquely identifies the user within the system.
This field is essential for user identification and is often used for login purposes or when addressing the user in the system.
The name of a user must adhere to the specified pattern and must be between 1 and 32 characters in length.

id.description: id of user. This property is set by the backend.

deletable.description: if ture, the user is deletable. This property is set by the backend.

systemuser.description: if ture, the user is a system user. This property is set by the backend.

deleteat.description: The time at which the system user will be deleted. This property is set by the backend.

passwordPolicyId.description: Id of the named password policy that is or shall applied to this user

useGlobalSessionSettings.description: If true, apply global session settings at next login. Otherwise use individual sessions settings.

remote.description: Shows if the user is a remote user. Remote user are managed remotely. This property is set by the backend.

Passwords.description: For changing password, user should provid old and new passwords.

Group.description: The "Group" object is a representation of the properties associated with a group on the system. It serves as a container for various group-related information and attributes.

name.description:
The "name" property represents the name of the group.
It is a string that uniquely identifies the group within the system.
This field is essential for group identification and is used to link certain users to a group.
The name of a local group must adhere to the specified pattern and must be between 1 and 32 characters in length.

id.description: id of group. This property is set by the backend.

deletable.description: if true, the group is deletable. This property is set by the backend.

remote.description: Shows if the group is a remote group. Remote group are managed remotely. This property is set by the backend.

access_token.description: Base64 encoded JSON Web Token (JWT). See RFC 7519 for details.

RequiredScope.description: The scope which might be required by another scope in order to perform a specific action.

example.purpose: This permission is required to switch system mode.

purpose.example: This permission is required to switch system mode.

deprecated.description: Indicates if the scope is deprecated and discouraged for future use

remember.description: number of old password in password history.

rejectUsername.description: If true, password is not allowed to contain username.

ForceChpasswd.description: Status, if the password should be changed at next login.

LoginLockedStatus.description: Login locked status of a user.

secret.description: This is used to set a new radius secret. When trying to set an encrypted secret, use the optional property encryptedPassword and leave this empty. Both properties must not be set at the same time.

encryptedPassword.description: Contains the encrypted radius secret, which is generated when getting the radius config with a valid cipherkey as query parameter. Can be used to set the radius secret when updating the radius config with the correct cipherkey as query parameter. Either the encryptedPassword or the cleartext radius secret can be set, both can't be set in the same request.

readOnlyUserPassword.description: This is used to set a new read-only user password. When trying to set an encrypted read-only user password, use the optional property encryptedPassword and leave this empty. Both properties must not be set at the same time.

encryptedPassword.description: Contains the encrypted read-only user password, which is generated when getting the LDAP config with a valid cipherkey as query parameter. Can be used to set the read-only user password when updating the ldap config with the correct cipherkey as query parameter. Either the encryptedPassword or the cleartext read-only password can be set, both can't be set in the same request.

chgpwd.description: if true, change password is possible.

Problem.description: This document defines a "problem detail" as a way  to carry machine-readable details of errors in a  HTTP response to avoid the need to define new error  response formats for HTTP APIs.

type.description:
A URI reference [RFC3986] that identifies the problem type. 
This specification encourages that, when dereferenced, 
it provide human-readable documentation for the problem type 
(e.g., using HTML [W3C.REC-html5-20141028]). When this member 
is not present, its value is assumed to be "about:blank".

title.description:
A short, human-readable summary of the problem type. 
It SHOULD NOT change from occurrence to occurrence of the problem, 
except for purposes of localization (e.g., using proactive content 
negotiation; see [RFC7231], Section 3.4).
If the response is a diagnostics message, it contains 
the text associated with the mainDiagnosisCode.
title.example: You do not have enough credit.

status.description:
The HTTP status code ([RFC7231], Section 6) generated by the 
origin server for this occurrence of the problem.

detail.description:
A human-readable explanation specific to this occurrence of the problem.
If the response is a diagnostics message, it contains the text associated with
the detailedDiagnosisCode.
detail.example: Your current balance is 30, but that costs 50.

instance.description:
A URI reference that identifies the specific occurrence of the problem.
It may or may not yield further information if dereferenced.

code.description:
An error code issued by the system that caused the original problem.
This code can be used to track down the root cause of the error.

mainDiagnosisCode.description:
The main diagnosis code is issued by the system that caused the problem.
This code can be used to track down the root cause and source of the error.
It can be used to search in the documentation for a solution.
It SHOULD NOT change from occurrence to occurrence of the same problem.

detailedDiagnosisCode.description:
The detailed diagnosis code issued by the system that caused the problem.
This code can be used to track down the detailed cause and source of the error.
It can be used to search in the documentation for a solution.
The detailed diagnosis code gives additional information about the cause of the error.
It SHOULD NOT change from occurrence to occurrence of the same problem.

dynamicDescription.description:
A dynamic description gives detailed information about the occurrence of a problem.
It can change between different occurrences of the same error.

severity.description: Severity of a problem as defined RFC5424 of the Syslog standard, see https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5424

links.description:
Collection of links to fix the problem. E.g. links to online user manual,
to an online community (using tags) or a developer chat (e.g. Slack).

moreInfo.description:
The moreInfo field allows you to add additional information that might be necessary to debug or trace down the cause of an error.
It might also contain information what is needed to resolve the problem.
There are loosely specified fields for specific problems that can be used in these situations, e.g.:
- On a 403 Forbidden error: The moreInfo can contain a field "requiredPermissions" with the required permissions seperated by comma
- On a 402 Payment required: The moreInfo can contain a field "requiredLicenses" with the required licenses seperated by comma

cause.description:
Sometimes a problem might be caused by problems that occure in other components or are the root cause of a problem. In this
case the related problems can be added as a cause. Since it might be possible that multiple components have problems on a single
action, cause is an array. E.g. Loading failed because several components where not able to load the configuration.

UploadAssertion.description: To upload system user assertion file.

certificate.description: File name of the client certificate used for the TLS connection. The certificate needs to be available as own certificate of "Network Security" in the certificate manager.

key.description: File name of the private key used for the TLS connection. The key needs to be available as own key of "Network Security" in the certificate manager.

ca.description: The name of a file that contains a set of trusted CA certificates used to validate the server certificate for the TLS connection. The certificates need to be available as ca certificates of "Network Security" in the certificate manager.

skipServerCertificateVerification.description: If true, skip server certificate verification. If false, the server certificate will be validated against the specified ca stored in the certificate manager as ca certificate of "Network Security".
